abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Basic Education Support
            Project for Niger were as follows: overall outcome was
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, and both the Bank and the borrower performance
            were moderately satisfactory. Some important project lessons
            learned were: (1) Teams should make sure that governments
            and the GPE are aware of the implications choices made with
            regards to options offered by the Bank. Retaining the same
            number of classrooms in the project after the decision to
            include taxes suggests that the government was not aware
            that the amount of financing would not be increased to
            include taxes. (2) Prepare communities properly if they are
            to participate in school construction. Some of the schools
            in the project were not completed because not all
            communities were aware that they should provide the windows
            and doors and finish the buildings and did not know details
            related to their contribution. (3) Community based approach
            to construction should be adopted in difficult to reach
            areas. Construction of classrooms in some areas had to be
            abandoned because contractors were unwilling to work in
            these areas when the security situation had deteriorated.
            (4) Limit project area coverage when resources are limited.
            When project inputs are limited investments should be
            concentrated in a limited area to reduce supervision costs.
            (5) Addressing girls' education requires attention to
            various constraints to their participation and the potential
            impact of this new approach to promote girls education
            should be explored further. Advocacy for increasing
            participation of girls in school should be combined with
            other interventions which address the economic and security
            issues which constrain access. The provision of cash prizes
            to families with the best performing girls helped reduce
            household costs and promote retention and should be further
            studied. (6) Construction of latrines is not sufficient for
            promoting girls' education. Provision of good
            sanitation in school to increase girls' enrollment
            should not be limited to provision of latrines but should be
            part of a package that facilitates proper use and
            maintenance of the latrines and an awareness program.
